facts.text: Writ Petition No. 95 of 1965 filed in Original Jurisdiction under Article 32 of the Constitution of India for enforcement of Fundamental Rights.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Writ Petition No. 95 of 1965. Petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for enforcement of Fundamental Rights. K. Garg, M. K. Ramamurthi, S. C. Agarwal and D. P. Singh, for the petitioner.

facts.text: Petition seeks writ of habeas corpus for release of petitioner Durgadas Shirali from detention under order by District Magistrate of Bhilwara under Rule 30(1)(b) of Defence of India Rules.

anchor.surface_text: In this case the petitioner-Durgadas Shirali has obtained a rule calling upon the respondents to show cause why a writ of habeas companypus should number be issued under Art. 32 of the Constitution directing his release from detention under an order passed by the District Magistrate of Bhilwara, Rajasthan under Rule 30 1   b  of the Defence of India Rules.

facts.text: Cause shown by Advocate-General of Rajasthan on behalf of respondents.

anchor.surface_text: Cause has be shown by the Advocate-General of Rajasthan on behalf of the respondents to whom numberice of the rule was ordered to be given.

facts.text: Petitioner Durgadas Shirali arrested on January 2, 1965 at Jaipur pursuant to detention order dated December 29, 1964 by Respondent No. 3 Shri Narayan Das Mehta, District Magistrate of Bhilwara.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner was arrested on January 2, 1965 at Jaipur in Pursuance of an order dated December 29, 1964 made by res- Pondent number 3, Shri Narayan Das Mehta, District Magistrate of Bhilwara which states as follows It is reliably brought to my numberice that the Leftist wing of the Communist Party has been carrying on antinational and pro-Chinese propaganda and are preparing to act as Pekings member.

facts.text: Detention order dated December 29, 1964 states that Leftist wing of Communist Party carrying on anti-national and pro-Chinese propaganda, preparing to act as Peking's men.

anchor.surface_text: It is reliably brought to my numberice that the Leftist wing of the Communist Party has been carrying on antinational and pro-Chinese propaganda and are preparing to act as Pekings member. The party having been formed at Pekings behest are preparing for widespread agitation with the object of establishing companymunist regime by subversion and violence.

facts.text: District Magistrate satisfied that Shri Durgadas Shirali of Bhilwara is Secretary of Leftist Wing of Communist Party and likely to act prejudicial to Defence of India, Civil Defence, India's relations with foreign powers, public safety, maintenance of public order.

anchor.surface_text: I am also satisfied from the report that Shri Durgadas Shirali of Bhilwara is the Secretary of the Leftist Wing of the Communist Party and he is likely to act in manner which is prejudicial to the Defence of India and Civil Defence, Indias relations with Foreign powers, public safety and the maintenance of the public order.

facts.text: District Magistrate directs Superintendent of Police, Bhilwara to arrest and detain Shri Durgadas Shirali in Bhilwara Jail until further orders under Rule 30(1)(b) Defence of India Rules 1962, delegated by Government of Rajasthan Notification No.1 F. 7/116 Home A.Cr.163 dated November 4, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: I, Narayan Das Mehta, District Magistrate, Bhilwara in exercise of the powers delegated to me under rule 30 1  clause  b  of the Defence of India Rules 1962 vide Government of Rajasthan Notification No.1 F. 7/1 16 Home A.Cr. 1 63 dated the 4th November, 1963 and all other powers enabling in that behalf direct the Superintendent of Police, Bhilwara that Shri Durga Das Shirali be arrested and detained in the Bhilwara Jail until further orders.

facts.text: Detention order reviewed on January 13, 1965 by Reviewing Authority who recommended confirmation.

anchor.surface_text: On January 13, 1965 the orders of the District Magistrate was reviewed by the Reviewing Authority who recommended that the detention order dated December 29, 1964 should be companyfirmed.

facts.text: State Government confirmed detention order by order No. F7/119 Home A-Cr. I/65 dated January 22, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: The State Government companyfirmed the detention order by its order No. F7/1 19 Home A-Cr.  I /65 dated January 22, 1965.

facts.text: Petitioner contended that District Magistrate did not apply mind to specific activities of petitioner and there was complete absence of material suggesting prejudicial conduct.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the petitioner it was companytended by Mr. Garg that the District Magistrate had number applied his mind to the specific activities of the petitioner and there was companyplete absence of material before the District Magistrate to suggest that the companyduct of the petitioner would be prejudicial to the Defence of India and Civil Defence, Indias relations with foreign powers, public safety and the maintenance of the public order.

facts.text: Petitioner contended that detention order was mala fide and illegal.

anchor.surface_text: It was, therefore, submitted on behalf of the appellant that the order of detention made by the District Magistrate was mala fide and illegal.

facts.text: One ground in detention order: petitioner member of Leftist Wing of Communist Party and Secretary of local branch at Bhilwara; party carrying anti-national pro-Chinese propaganda, constitutes danger to security.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Garg submitted, in the second place, that one of the grounds mentioned in the order of detention was that the petitioner was a member of the Leftist Wing of the Communist Party of India and Secretary of the local branch of that party at Bhilwara.

facts.text: Leftist wing of Communist Party not declared illegal or banned by Government of India.

anchor.surface_text: It was submitted by Mr. Garg that the Leftist wing of the Communist Party had number been declared illegal or banned by the Government of India and the membership of the petitioner of the Leftist Communist Party of India was, therefore, number a relevant ground for the order of detention.

facts.text: District Magistrate filed affidavit stating satisfied from reports that petitioner carrying on anti-national and pro-Chinese propaganda as member of Leftist Wing.

anchor.surface_text: In paragraph 3 of the a davit the District Magistrate has stated that he was satisfied from the reports -that the petitioner was carrying on anti-national and pro Chinese propaganda as a member of the Leftist Wing of the Communist Party.

facts.text: District Magistrate stated in affidavit paragraph 5 that he passed detention order after satisfying himself on reports that petitioner was Secretary of Leftist Wing CPI Bhilwara branch and likely prejudicial.

anchor.surface_text: In paragraph 5 the District Magistrate has stated that he passed the order of detention after satisfying himself on the reports that the petitioner was the Secretary of the Leftist Wing of the Communist Party of India, Bhilwara branch and that he was likely to act in a manner prejudicial to Defence of India and Civil Defence, Indias relations with foreign powers, public safety and the maintenance of public order.

facts.text: Court holds that District Magistrate did apply mind to specific activities of petitioner based on affidavit.

anchor.surface_text: In view of the affidavit of the District Magistrate it is number possible for us to accept the argument of Mr. Garg that the District Magistrate did number apply his mind to the specific activities of the petitioner and that he made the order of detention solely on the ground that the Leftist wing of the Communist Party of India was carrying on anti-national and pro-Chinese propaganda.

facts.text: Petitioner argued that membership in Leftist wing CPI not per se illegal and irrelevant ground for detention under Rule 30.

anchor.surface_text: It was next argued on behalf of the petitioner that the Leftist wing of the Communist Party of India has number been declared illegal by the Government of India and the party has number been banned. It was submitted, therefore, that membership of that party was number per se illegal and the order of detention of the petitioner cannot be legally based upon this ground.

facts.text: Court holds that political association and membership of petitioner in Leftist wing CPI is relevant consideration with proximate connection to security of State and public order under Rule 30.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, in the light of the reports received by the District Magistrate the political association of the petitioner and his membership of a particular political group is a relevant companysideration in the matter of detention of the petitioner. This ground has close and proximate companynection with the security of State and maintenance of public order as companytemplated by Rule 30 of the Defence of India Rules.

facts.text: Court holds that petitioner has not made out case for grant of writ under Article 32.

anchor.surface_text: For these reasons we hold that the petitioner has number made .out a case for the grant of a writ under Art.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Garg submitted, in the second place, that one of the grounds mentioned in the order of detention was that the petitioner was a member of the Leftist Wing of the Communist Party of India and Secretary of the local branch of that party at Bhilwara. The Leftist Communist Party has been carrying on antinational and pro-Chinese propaganda... arguments.claim: Membership of the Leftist wing of the Communist Party of India is not per se illegal and cannot legally be the basis for detention under Rule 30; irrelevant ground vitiates entire order (citing Shibban Lal Saksena)

anchor.surface_text: It was next argued on behalf of the petitioner that the Leftist wing of the Communist Party of India has not been declared illegal by the Government of India and the party has not been banned. It was submitted, therefore, that membership of that party was not per se illegal and the order of detention of the petitioner cannot be legally based upon this ground.

arguments.claim: District Magistrate did apply mind to specific activities of petitioner based on affidavit; order not solely on party activities

anchor.surface_text: In view of the affidavit of the District Magistrate it is not possible for us to accept the argument of Mr. Garg that the District Magistrate did not apply his mind to the specific activities of the petitioner and that he made the order of detention solely on the ground that the Leftist wing of the Communist Party of India was carrying on anti-national and pro-Chinese propaganda.

arguments.claim: Political association and membership of petitioner in Leftist wing CPI is relevant consideration with close and proximate connection to security of State and maintenance of public order under Rule 30

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, in the light of the reports received by the District Magistrate the political association of the petitioner and his membership of a particular political group is a relevant consideration in the matter of detention of the petitioner. This ground has close and proximate connection with the security of State and maintenance of public order as contemplated by Rule 30 of the Defence of India Rules.

arguments.claim: Challenges to detention on grounds of mala fides or irrelevant grounds (no real proximate connection) are permissible despite Presidential Order under Art. 359(1) and Art. 358 (citing Makhan Singh)

anchor.surface_text: Before proceeding to deal with these points raised on behalf of the petitioner it is necessary to state that in Makhan Singh Tarsikka v. The State of Punjab this Court had occasion to consider the legal effect of the proclamation of Emergency... It is not also open to challenge the Ordinance rule or order made thereunder on the ground of contravention of Art. 19... But a petitioner can challenge... on a ground other than those covered by Art. 358, or the Presidential Order issued under Art. 359(1). ... a citizen will not be deprived of his right to move... on the ground that his detention has been ordered mala fide. Similarly, it will be open to the citizen to challenge the order of detention on the ground that any of the grounds given in the order of detention is irrelevant and there is no real and proximate connection...

holdings.text: In view of the affidavit of the District Magistrate it is not possible for us to accept the argument of Mr. Garg that the District Magistrate did not apply his mind to the specific activities of the petitioner and that he made the order of detention solely on the ground that the Leftist wing of the Communist Party of India was carrying on anti-national and pro-Chinese propaganda.

anchor.surface_text: In view of the affidavit of the District Magistrate it is not possible for us to accept the argument of Mr. Garg that the District Magistrate did not apply his mind to the specific activities of the petitioner and that he made the order of detention solely on the ground that the Leftist wing of the Communist Party of India was carrying on anti-national and pro-Chinese propaganda.

holdings.reasoning_summary: DM's affidavit in paras 3 and 5 confirms satisfaction based on reports of petitioner's specific anti-national and pro-Chinese activities as member and secretary of Leftist Wing.

holdings.text: In our opinion, in the light of the reports received by the District Magistrate the political association of the petitioner and his membership of a particular political group is a relevant consideration in the matter of detention of the petitioner. This ground has close and proximate connection with the security of State and maintenance of public order as contemplated by Rule 30 of the Defence of India Rules.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, in the light of the reports received by the District Magistrate the political association of the petitioner and his membership of a particular political group is a relevant consideration in the matter of detention of the petitioner. This ground has close and proximate connection with the security of State and maintenance of public order as contemplated by Rule 30 of the Defence of India Rules.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Reports link petitioner's role in Leftist Wing (carrying pro-Chinese propaganda, preparing subversion) to Rule 30 objects; not irrelevant merely because party not banned; distinguishes Shibban Lal Saksena.

holdings.text: For these reasons we hold that the petitioner has not made out a case for the grant of a writ under Art. 32.

anchor.surface_text: For these reasons we hold that the petitioner has not made out a case for the grant of a writ under Art.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects claims of non-application of mind and irrelevant grounds after examining affidavit and reports; detention order valid under Rule 30(1)(b).

holdings.text: A petitioner can challenge the validity of the order of detention on a ground other than those covered by Art. 358, or the Presidential Order issued under Art. 359(1). Such a challenge is outside the purview of the Presidential Order. For instance, a citizen will not be deprived of his right to move an appropriate Court for a writ of habeas corpus on the ground that his detention has been ordered mala fide. Similarly, it will be open to the citizen to challenge the order of detention on the ground that any of the grounds given in the order of detention is irrelevant and there is no real and proximate connection between the ground given and the object which the legislature has in view.

anchor.surface_text: Before proceeding to deal with these points raised on behalf of the petitioner it is necessary to state that in Makhan Singh Tarsikka v. The State of Punjab 1  this Court had occasion to consider the legal effect of the proclamation of Emergency issued by the President on October 26, 1962 and two orders of the President-one dated November 3, 1962 and the other dated November 11, 1962 issued in exercise of the powers conferred by cl.  1  of Art. 359 of the Constitution. It was held by this Court that the sweep of Art. 359 1  and the Presidential Order issued under it is wide enough to include all claims made by citizens in any Court of competent jurisdiction when it is shown that the said claims cannot be effectively adjudicated upon without examining the question as to whether the citizen is, in substance, seeking to enforce fundamental rights under Arts. 14, 19, 21 and 22.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Following Makhan Singh, Art. 359(1) bars enforcement of specified rights but permits challenges to detention on mala fides or irrelevant grounds lacking proximate nexus.

precedents.citation: Makhan Singh Tarsikka v. The State of Punjab 1

The State of Punjab 1  this Court had occasion to companysider the legal effect of the proclamation of Emergency issued by the President on October 26, 1962 and two orders of the President-one dated November 3, 1962 and the other dated November 11, 1962 issued in exercise of the powers companyferred by cl.  1  of Art. 359 of the Constitution.

precedents.case_name: Makhan Singh Tarsikka v. State of Punjab
precedents.cited_proposition: Legal effect of proclamation of Emergency and Presidential Orders under Art. 359(1); bar on enforcing Arts. 14, 19, 21, 22 does not preclude challenges to detention orders on other grounds like mala fides or irrelevant grounds
precedents.cited_holding: the sweep of Art. 359(1) and the Presidential Order issued under it is wide enough to include all claims... but... open to challenge... on the ground that his detention has been ordered mala fide... or that any of the grounds given... is irrelevant

precedents.citation: Shibban Lal Saksena v. The State of Uttar Pradesh ,- .

anchor.surface_text: In support of his argument Mr. Garg referred to the decision of this. Court in Shibban Lal Saksena v. The State of Uttar Pradesh ,- . We are unable to accept the argument of Mr. Garg as companyrect.

precedents.cited_proposition: Order of detention vitiated if any ground is irrelevant or illusory

anchor.surface_text: In view of the affidavit of the District Magistrate it is not possible for us to accept the argument of Mr. Garg that the District Magistrate did not apply his mind to the specific activities of the petitioner and that he made the order of detention solely on the ground that the Leftist wing of the Communist Party of India was carrying on anti-national and pro-Chinese propaganda.
For these reasons we hold that the petitioner has number made .out a case for the grant of a writ under Art.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, in the light of the reports received by the District Magistrate the political association of the petitioner and his membership of a particular political group is a relevant consideration in the matter of detention of the petitioner. This ground has close and proximate connection with the security of State and maintenance of public order as contemplated by Rule 30 of the Defence of India Rules.
For these reasons we hold that the petitioner has number made .out a case for the grant of a writ under Art.

anchor.surface_text: Before proceeding to deal with these points raised on behalf of the petitioner it is necessary to state that in Makhan Singh Tarsikka v. The State of Punjab 1  this Court had occasion to consider the legal effect of the proclamation of Emergency issued by the President on October 26, 1962 and two orders of the President-one dated November 3, 1962 and the other dated November 11, 1962 issued in exercise of the powers conferred by cl.  1  of Art. 359 of the Constitution. It was held by this Court that the sweep of Art. 359 1  and the Presidential Order issued under it is wide enough to include all claims made by citizens in any Court of competent jurisdiction when it is shown that the said claims cannot be effectively adjudicated upon without examining the question as to whether the citizen is, in substance, seeking to enforce fundamental rights under Arts. 14, 19, 21 and 22.
For these reasons we hold that the petitioner has number made .out a case for the grant of a writ under Art.
